column10: b"b' changed: upgrade memory based cache to filebased after having been full f'"
b'b" changed: upgrade memory based cache to filebased after having been full for 2 seconds without anything reading out of it By starting out with a memory based cache
column11: then replacing that with a file based one on need we avoid the rather large overhead a file based cache introduces. However it can currently not discern the difference between paused playback on a really fast network
column12: and on a slow one. So if you play over http from local network for example and pause playback. The whole file will be downloaded to local disk at maximum network speed. I\'m hesitant to this feature. I suspect it must be possible to turn on and off. On embedded system we may not have diskspace enough to do this. And currently i don\'t think the file based cache handles the situation of running out of space well at all. Comments are very welcome to how we should handle a feature like this."'

column10: b"b' Seems to work quite well under OSX. No issues that I can see yet. iOS testing tonight.'"

b'b" Nice to hear. I\'ve realized a rather major bug with the file based cache thou which must be fixed before this goes in. If the free disk space of the local machine does not support the size of the streamed file
column11: playback will break down. So two things really needs to be fixed here. One verify available disk space. Define some limit as to how much free space we always must leave. Something like atleast 200 megs (computers do funny things when totally out of disk space). Fix the SimpleFileCache to wrap around similary to how the new mem buffer does. So it doesn\'t break down with a limited amount of disk space."'

column10: b'b" what\'s a good way to trigger this ? iOS is fine but I don\'t really see the file cache getting created."'
b"b' Normally it would just be pause playback on a file larger than 20megs+8_video byterate
column11: wait for the file cache to fill larger than 20+8_videobyterate. (is visible in the codec info data)'"

column16: another nice thing might be to support skipping within the already cached video
column17: but refusing to try to skip beyond the cache limit because we know we won\'t be able to. i hope my suggestions help!"'

column10: b'b" As far as the patches go
column11: they look good.  It looks like the limit type (or lack of bounds check) problem I\'d mention on IRC was already handled.  I still don\'t really understand why we need multiple jobs though?  Should the totals job run with any other the DB access will effectively serialize their tasks.  It seems like excessive thread creation with little to no gain and I\'m guessing the blocking could be costly when using a remote DB.  Couldn\'t we just pass the flags into the job ctor and use that to pick which stuff to query the DB for in the work function? I do disagree with the inclusion of this patch on the principle that this feature is exactly of the type we are trying to move OUT of core.  I can\'t help but figure it will just be moved right back out to an addon at some point in the (hopefully near) future.  Is extending the addon interface to support the bits this adds really not an option?"'

column10: b'b" ofc it _can_ be done as an add-on. but what do we gain? core would still have to issue the refresh. and i can\'t think of a single other usecase for such a class of add-ons. as for starting threads
column11: they are much cheaper than spawning a python interpreter will ever be."'

column10: b"b' multiple jobs are there to handle different cases. we dont want to update all when only watched status is changing or update music RA if only one new movie has been added'"
b'b" @spiffGains would be the ability to choose different RA implementations which provide varying degrees of info.  I for one don\'t desire anything more than title
column11: path
column12: date and thumb
column13: where I\'m sure there are others who want the whole mediainfo window.  Additionally
column14: I can see there being a fair number of settings associated with this.  As an addon
column15: we don\'t have to worry about yet more clutter in core settings. @amet:I understand what they\'re used for
column16: just not why they\'re needed.  It seems the job selection logic could be moved into a single RA::DoWork() and the relevant bits of the individual jobs DoWork() selected there."'

column10: b'b\' Personally I agree that we could drop to a single job that you pass your flag to (i.e. AddRecentlyAddedJobs would just add a single job passing the flag to the constructor) it would save on contention with the jobmanager as really you want all the jobs specified by the flag run before you update the UI anyway.  In addition it\\\'d save locks on the database during a scan. You could still have separate classes to do the separate things if you think that\\\'s better
column11: though IMO separate functions is fine as well you\\\'d simply call each of those  in the DoWork() routine of the one job. However I don\\\'t see a huge benefit in providing less information after all
column12: it\\\'s up to the skin as to what they choose to display and as we don\\\'t know this in advance (necessarily at least) it\\\'s easier just to grab the lot.  Especially given that grabbing everything versus grabbing a subset has very little impact on performance
column13: even if the sql queries were optimised to the n-th degree. In the future
column14: the "listing" portion of RA would be done by simply retrieving a directory
column15: so that portion of the jobs will be going away the "totals" portion would then be all that remains
column16: which would be general infolabels.\''

column10: b'b\' OK. So. Here\\\'s the outcome of this pull request. In a perfect world :-)
column11: XBMC will show weather for the current location the first time it\\\'s run. (When the user switches locations using the weather location slider
column12: XBMC remembers this.) But it also degrades quite well for the following situations:1. _Location fails due to no network_ not important
column13: because without internet what good is weather?2. _Location fails when set to "current location" (e.g. first time xbmc is run)_ Upon visiting the weather screen
column14: user is given the option to change to a predefined location3. _Same as above
column15: but user clicks cancel instead of changing the location_ A location refresh is triggered. If it succeeds
column16: we\\\'re in our perfect world. If it fails
column17: back to # 2. If it fails and the user is a ninja and quickly returns to the weather screen (so the location update is still in progress)
column18: on to # 5.4. _Location fails when set to a predifined location_ "Current location" is simply skipped on the weather location slider5. _Location is set to "current location"
column19: but the user checks weather before location has a chance to fail (mid-update)_ When location eventually does fail
column20: a NOTIFY_ALL msg is sent and # 2 occurs6. _Location fails but is eventually refreshed and then succeeds (weather set to "current location")_ When weather finishes refreshing we return to our perfect world scenario7. _Location fails but is eventually refreshed and then succeeds (weather set to pre-defined location)_ Current location is added on the weather location slider Does that address all the cases? If there\\\'s any I missed
column21: lemme know\''

New York" etc. The advantage of this is that the user gets to have 3 well-defined locations and a fourth automatic one.\''

b"b' Escaped info support to builtin parameter parsing'"
b'b" Many skinners use ()\'s as input into some other built in function
column11: which means that skin labels (that use $INFO[]) may be passed into builtin functions as parameters. The problem is if the label contains quotes then the builtin function parsing does weird things. This solves this via 2 methods:1.  We only remove quotes from parameters if they\'re the first and last character (ignoring whitespace) of the parameters.2.  We introduce a new $ESCINFO[] which is identical to $INFO[] but the result is altered by first escaping any quotes
column12: and then wraps the result in quotes. Comments welcome I\'ll commit in a couple of days if nothing obvious is discovered."'

column10: b'b" Don\'t destroy control objects on window deinit"'
b'b" Window\'s controls are being deleted on window deinit. This results in loading xml
column11: resolving includes
column12: parsing resolved xml and creating controls everytime user activate window. This will allow to keep controls objects in memory on window deinit (if system has enough free memory). pros: skipping unnecessary I/O operations (loading xml file) better user experience (faster UI) cons:higher memory usage it\'s not significent increase but this could be issue for some platforms (f.e. ) in my commits I have this feature turned on by default there could be some #ifdef to change default setting for some platforms notes:skinners should be noticed to use ReloadSkin() builtin exclusively to refresh window"'

column10: b'b" Handle textures in the texture manager. won\'t do anything if the texturemanager doesn\'t actually free the resource.  I suggest just having a reasonably long timeout before deletion (similar to the way the largetexturemanager does it).  Ideally this would be done by merging the normal + large texture managers together (i.e. all requests for textures go through the largetexturemanager which keeps the list of allocated textures the g_textureManager would then pretty much just handle interfacing with the texturebundles
column11: or be removed altogether.  If you want to take a crack at that next
column12: then by all means go for it :) In the meantime
column13: I say we merge as-is (I\'ll have another check over things first and then pull) with the  setting in place we can always remove it later or modify it to suit once it\'s been tested well on embedded platforms."'

column10: b'b\' I took a look in texture managers and possible would like to merge them. Current timeout for large textures is 2000ms (+up to 500ms interval of trigerring releasing of unused textures) after decrementing refcount to 0 this seems to be reasonable. Also from quick look it seems that loading texture (not large one) blocks context do You think that creating CJob to load textures is worth consideration? (one thread that loads textures from "texture queue") There could be also some mechanism for skins to define GUI textures that shouldn\\\'t be released even if currently not used (i.e. button backgrounds) or to assign custom  for them.\''

b'b\' Great!1.  Background loading vs non-background loading is the point of the  flag in the XML.  Any textures without this MUST be loaded blocking as animation timing etc. may well depend on the texture being there immediately.  With that said
column11: there\\\'s no reason we couldn\\\'t have "if background = true
column12: load via the job" I think currently textures are loaded directly rather than via the job if they\\\'re in the XPR.2.  IMO the "should a texture be released" call should be made by the engine
column13: not the skin.  Reason is simple: we can do it so why should skinners have to? The idea is to track both usage (reference count + a history count + memory use) and roll out textures that aren\\\'t used much (low history count) when their reference count is zero and a suitable delay has taken place.  In addition
column14: memory use tracking allows us to check available memory and roll textures out if needed either immediately or as required.  The first two are the most important. Having simple dumb reference count + delay as per the large texture manager would be a good first step (i.e. merge them).\''

column10: b"b' Decoupling of mute status and volume level'"
b'b\' With these changes the mute status and volume level become independant. If audio is muted at 0% volume and then unmuted
column11: volume will be set back to 0% (and not 100% as it was until now).Furthermore when "Volume Up" or "Volume Down" is executed during muted audio
column12: it will be unmuted and the action will be applied to the restored volume level.I have checked how this is done on TVs from Samsung
column13: Sony
column14: Phillips and LG and they all do this the same way as this implementation works (so does Win7 and probably any Linux distro and OSX as well but I haven\\\'t checked those). Furthermore I have changed the format of how the volume is displayed from a negative dB value to a positive percentage value. IMO this is much more intuitive for non-geek users. Having your audio at 100% but seeing "0.0 dB" is a bit odd at a quick glance.\''

column10: b'b\' I don\\\'t think it makes sense to unmute to 0%. I explicitely implemented it to unmute to 100% so one can easily "return" to 100% volume. And else one can use the arrow up button to start from 0%\''

b'b" Like I wrote in the description I checked lots of different TVs from different manufacturers and Windows and Ubuntu do this the same way. If we handle this differently it is very unintuitive for users not extremely familiar with XBMC. I use XBMC for a couple of years now and I still find it very confusing. I actually started changing the implementation because it nearly blew my ears (and woke all my neighbours) last weekend when my GF didn\'t find the mute button and therefore moved from 50% volume to 0%. I thought the sound was muted and pressed the Mute button again and audio went up to 100% (I normally keep it around 50-60% because 100% is far too loud with my setup). I expect that some people think about this differently so here\'s the place to discuss this :-)"'
b'b" I\'m with Montellese here. We should implement it the way the user expects it. And as already was described nearly all entertainment hardware handles it like presented in this request."'

b"b' I find it logical how this is implemented here. Mute and Volume should not interfer with each other. Unmute should allways restore the previous set volume. And if it was zero then pebcak or the user wanted it that way :)'"
b'b" The mute changes look fine.  I\'m not convinced of the volume change to percentage
column11: primarily as they were designed to allow "'

column10: b"b' New audio codec for pcm streams'"
b"b' Hi
column11: I created a new audio codec for processing pcm files and streams.This is needed because remote UPnP / DLNA media servers deliver pcm by default.The pcm format has mime type  and file extensions .pcm or .l16.Regards
column12: AndrewFG'"

column10: b"b' I would suggest making the constructor take the actual info
column11: i.e. CPCMCodec(samplerate
column12: channels
column13: bitspersample) and have the parsing in codecfactory.'"

column10: b"b' I wanted to stay within the argument template of the base class. So instead of messing with the construcor
column11: I added a new method. Note also that when opening a file
column12: the old argument template must be called with void arguments (because no mime type data is available); whereas when opening an HTTP stream
column13: the mime type data must to be passed in too. I suppose that one could have two constructors; but the alternative way (what I chose) is to have a single constructor plus an additional method to take in the mime type data...'"

column10: b'b" I generally just like when static stuff (which I consider a codec being) are ready and initialized right after the constructor
column11: but PAPCodecs are more of a stream read + demux + codec mix so it doesn\'t apply really :)I took a look again at the code and it looks like PAP does Constructor
column12: then INIT
column13: so the actual resolve can\'\'t be in the constructor as you say
column14: I\'m not 100% confident in that particular code so it would be nice one of the devs who knows that code well (not sure who is maintainer of paplayer tbh) takes a look at it
column15: otherwise I think its fine and probably ready for merge."'

column10: b'b\' The constructor initializes the properties to the defaults defined for the L16 pcm mime-type ( i.e. 2 channel / 44100Hz ).Then SetMimeParams() only overrides the defaults if the mime-type string contains "rate=48000" or "channels=1" modifiers.And then Init() is called to open the file / stream itself.\''

b'b\' I solved the problem.Actually xbmc is very strict concerning the sequence in which DLNA ProtocolInfo attributes are offered; and it was rejecting the server\\\'s offers as being out of sequence . Having re-read the DLNA specs
column11: it seems that xbmc is compliant with the letter of the specification
column12: so I have corrected this "bug" on the media server side
column13: (However personally I would have suggested that xbmc should be more lenient).However
column14: another bigger problem arose in the process: my PCMCodec does not work! =I think the problem is due to  Endian issues; the  mime-type specifies network byte order
column15: and I think I need to swap the byte order for the xmbc Windows application; and I suppose this would be different for a Unix build. =\''

column10: b'b\' say your github account remote is called andrewfg and xbmc main github remote is origin then: First create a copy of your branch where you make changes: then: This will open an editor where you can re-organize your commits. What you want to do is keep the first
column11: then change the "pick" work of the others to "squash" or just "s". That way they will be combined into the first commit. When done you save and close the editor. Git will then try to do what you asked
column12: and if it finds conflicts with upstream it will stop letting you edit the files to resolve the conflicts. If you had conflicts and have resolved them
column13: then you do git rebase continue to finish the process. Then when done you push your new branch to the same branch name you initiated this pull request (git push -f [remote] [source branchname]:[target branchname]. The -f param is needed since you are rewriting history of the remote branch. (ie replacing it)  \''

column11: I missed your latest commits.  Note that there\'s no need to merge from  into your feature branch
column12: unless you need something from  it just makes things unnecessarily messy. Two things need doing:1.  Get rid of borderDiffuse.  There is no case for it being required that I can see (i.e. it\'s achievable directly by using a bordered texture to begin with).2.  Sort out the difference between m_diffuseColor and m_.  If a control sets a diffuse color what should take priority?  Currently you overwrite with the texture\'s color.  I wonder whether a colour multiply might be more appropriate?  Note that this has implications for dirty region rendering by overwriting m_diffuseColor
column13: the next time the color gets set the control will be marked dirty even though it\'s not. Comment in the thread once you\'ve made the changes for some reason I didn\'t get email notification about it before."'

column10: b'b" OK it\'s nothing to do with the action handling. If I play a video then at 10:55:30 I move the mouse and wheel down
column11: the log (with a few extra logging lines of my own and midly edited) shows: So the OSD appears at 10:55:30 in response to the mousemove
column12: and the SeekBar responds to the wheel down at 10:55:31. however nothing happens until the OSD times out and disappears at 10:55:38. As soon as this happens the SeekBar window is initialised and DVDPlayer does the seek. So it\'s the presence of the OSD dialog that is blocking the SeekBar from doing the seek. The action is getting queued somewhere and only released when the OSD is de-initialised. I can see two fixes for this. One is to find out why the OSD is blocking the SeekBar
column13: and the other is to simply close the OSD before opening the SeekBar. This is of course what I originally suggested. I\'m unwilling to look any further into why the OSD dialog is blocking the SeekBar. It\'s not an area of the code I know and there must be others who know this code well enough to quickly see what the problem is."'

This was aimed to be 1:1 transition with minimal behaviour changesOnly thing that I changed is that if given  is empty then moving stored settings from  to addon_ it will assign default value (if skinner provide default value in ) <benefit of this is shown in last commit skinners don\'t have to worry about providing default mechanism in layout files. Notes:Somewhere between dharma and master skin settings become case sensitive I think we should make them insenstive (as everything else that skinner use to exec  info from infomanager is case insenstive). I couldn\'t get rid of m_() in CSettings (at time we are parsing  addon manager is not yet inited). This should be marked to be removed after Eden. About added hack to enable using it without  this should be removed sooner or later. I added this just to not break every skin there is and give time to skinners to adjust. Also I would consider dropping setting saving each time we change value of setting and launch it only when we unload skin but didn\'t want to bring more changes than we need to this PR."'

b"b' fix movie stacking when additional files are present in a directory'"
b'b" If I\'m reading the code correctly
column11: the stacking algorithm is: for every file in this CFileItemList
column12: check whether it matches any stacking regexp; if it does
column13: check if other files in this CFileItemList match the same regexp this file does
column14: starting with the next object in this CFileItemList. Yet
column15: lines 2256-2257 cause the algorithm to skip checking the remaining list items if the file following _file1_ is not stackable with _file1_ (e.g. subtitles). This is somewhat challenging to explain
column16: so let me give an example. Imagine a file list containing 4 items: 1: 2: 3: 4:  Now let\'s assume the user has set a stacking regexp that only matches AVI files (like in my case)
column17: e.g.:The first item matches this regexp. The algorithm should check (starting with item 2) whether the remaining items also match this regexp and whether or not they are stackable (matching title
column18: ignore
column19: extension; mismatching volume) with item 1. Yet
column20: because item 2 does not match the stacking regexp
column21: lines 2256-2257 will restart the algorithm for item 1 with a different regexp instead of giving the algorithm a chance to find other files matching the regexp and stackable with item 1 (namely item 3) in the rest of the list. I believe the wrong iterator is incremented at line 2256 and that line 2257 should not read _break_ but rather _continue_ instead. If I\'m right about the above
column22: I believe the other _expr++/break_ combos also need to be changed. I\'ve come across this issue when some of my movies failed to stack properly only when subtitles were present in the same directory. This patch hasn\'t broken anything in my XBMC installation
column23: yet obviously it needs to be reviewed by someone with better insight into XBMC\'s inner workings. Maybe I am missing something here."'

column10: b'b\' I don\\\'t have any stackable video files so I\\\'m not really affected by this. But let\\\'s assume I have all my movies in one directory with an NFO
column11: a poster and fanart for each movie. Let\\\'s further assume I have a rather huge movie library (1000+ movies). That means I have at least 4000+ files in that directory. If every movie is divided into two parts it would even be 5000+ files. With your change the stacking logic will take the first video file and check it against all the other 3999/4999+ files (if there is no match) and then start with the next expression. Once that is done it moves on to the second file and checks the first expression against the remaining 3998/4998+ files and so on. That will result in one hell of a lot of iterations compared to the current implementation which does 2 checks per non-stackable item per expression. And regular expressions aren\\\'t among the cheap instructions. I agree that the current logic is not perfect and needs improving but I think just going through all the files might result in a noticeable slowdown depending on how many files are in a directory. I don\\\'t know about all the different flavours of stack-naming conventions out there in the wild but in your case a check for "does the current filename only differ in the extension" and depending on that check either aborting or moving to the next item would already solve your problem. This is far from perfect as well but I just wanna point out that it might be worth coming up with a better solution.\''

column10: b'b" Point taken. I guess it all comes down to the way the user organizes  files. In my case every movie is in a separate folder
column11: so the overhead introduced is undetectable. I agree with your argumentation
column12: though. I\'ve initially pictured this issue as a bug due to the fact that even when I had set the stacking regexps properly
column13: my movies weren\'t stacked unless the video files were the only files in a movie\'s folder. I\'ll report back if I come up with something more brilliant ;)"'

column10: b'b\' Well it is a bug so no need to close the PR (you can also  your commit with a better approach and it will automatically be added to the PR). It can be used as a discussion platform for a better solution. Finding a good solution highly depends on covering all the "more common" use cases for naming conventions of stacked files and files associated with stacked files (subtitles etc).\''

column11: thus would have been filtered out before we get to the Stack() routine.  My guess is your problem files are different than this
column12: such as .ifo ?"'

column10: b'b" This should be a straight forward fix.  There\'s a validity check for the file types but it currently only excludes folders
column11: nfo files
column12: and playlists file types.  It needs to be change to skip folder and anything that\'s not a video file.  Using !item1->IsVideo() and  !item2->IsVideo() should do it.  (May need to leave in IsPlayList() though.  They may be in the video extension list.)"'

column10: b'b" Heh.  I was just about to comment on that.  They shouldn\'t even be in the list!"'
b'b" I have an idea about this.  If this only occurs when you specifically set an extension in the RegExp
column11: I bet it\'s because you have two different valid video file types for the same movie.  For example:  Movie1.CD1.avi
column12: Movie1.CD1.mp4
column13: Movie1.CD2.avi
column14: Movie2.CD2.mp4."'

column10: b'b\' Is "stack" the magic word to invoke you? ;)\''
b'b" Yes :)  I remember spending a lot of time on that many
column11: many moons ago so the bug caught my eye. I was curious how much the code had changed since then
column12: and I was surprised to find it\'s not much. And I distinctly remember an issue related to multiple copies of a movie
column13: with the same exact name but in different formats
column14: breaking the stack functionality.  "'

column10: b'b" An srt subtitle file is not the problem.  It\'s a combination of another valid videofile type extension with the same name as your avi.  The fact that you have the extension listed is irrelevant.  The problem exists with my example earlier even with the default regular expressions which are not extension specific
column11: but both conditions should be corrected. One way that comes to mind which should mean no changes to the stacking code at all would be to define a new sort method that sorts by filename and by the extension independently so that you get this output order.  Movie-CD1.aviMovie-CD2.aviMovie-CD1.mp4Movie-CD2.mp4 The other option is to change the stack routine not to skip to the next reg expression until encountering an item with a different first character than the one being tested as that ensures that there\'s no possible match thereafter. The question is which one will require fewer total iterations of the entire list.  "'

column10: b"b' [fix] let the scripts react on the abortRequested flag before killing them'"

b'b" This fixes the shutdown of python scripts. Until now we set abortRequested true and then raised the SystemExit exception on each running python thread in a running python script. There was no chance for the script to react on the abortRequested flag because we didn\'t even release the Global Interpreter Lock. This is an example script which didn\'t shutdown properly: url  This PR realises the following shutdown flow:1. When script gets stopped set the abortRequested flag to the scripts module2. Release the GIL and wait for stoppedEvent to get set for up to 5 secs (thats the time where the script and its threads can react on the abortRequested flag)3. Meanwhile the script can shutdown and the PyThread should go out of his Process() handler4. When Process() is nearly finished set the stoppedEvent and wait on the m_pExecuter->m_critSection which is entered by the ::stop method at that time5. ::stop gets signaled and locks the GIL again6. ::stop function now kills all remaining threads in that script by raising the SystemExit exception7. ::stop leaves the m_pExecuter->m_critSection8. ::Process handler is able to enter it now and shuts down the interpreter for that script. And done we are. This allows a really clean shutdown. But would be nice if jimfcarroll or anyone else could have a look. Thx to cptspiff for the open ear :) PS: i would like this to be eden code ..."'
b'b\' "this event has to be fired without holding m_pExecuter->m_critSection" Why? Should be enough to just leave section after setting the event? \''

b'b\' What i wanted to say with this is when we are on that point where the event is set we are also in the ::stopped method waiting on that event and are inside of m_pExecuter->m_critSection.  So moving the  down a view lines after the Process method trys to enter that section it will have to wait until ::stopped metho leaves the section. And this happens only when  times out in that case. It should read "this event has to be fired without holding m_pExecuter->m_critSection before" (this one slipped onto the next line). Not sure how to phrase it correctly...\''

b"b' I think we should probably set abortRequested + raiseKeyboardInterrupt exception only in main thread. Otherwise scriptsneed to keep polling abortRequested which will take quite a while. Then wait 5 secs for stop and then raise SystemExit in all threads.'"

b'b" If i understand the code correctly the abortRequested flag is automagically visible to all threads of the script isn\'t it? Imho its part of the addon itself to implement a proper shutdown mechanism. I for myself poll the abortRequested flag only in the mainthread and when triggered call appropriate shutdown methods of the other threads. Whats that keyboardinterrupt for?"'
b"b' keyboardinterrupt is the same as Ctrl+C for a normal python process(and can be caught if wanted). Polling is silly since it just causespointless cpu usage.'"

b'b" gotcha i will add raise of keyboardinterrupt then ... though most of the scripts might want to poll for changed settings where this approach doesn\'t help anything. Polling is a need for situations where we just can\'t callback. Sad and nasty but you know its true ;)."'

b'b\' But the polling for abortRequested is already there (i.e. it hasn\\\'t been added by this PR) and most (service) scripts use it. So raising KeyboardInterrupt kind of changes the behaviour of the shutdown sequence and "breaks" (by automatically force closing them) current scripts
column11: doesn\\\'t it? If that\\\'s the case I\\\'m not sure if the KeyboardInterrupt will be a good addition if this is meant for Eden.\''

column10: b'b\' Current behavior is "kill em all".. It throws SystemExit exceptions which should not be catchable in all threads (ie the setting of abortRequested is nothing plugins have a chance to react on). So setting abortRequested and throwing a KeyboardInterrupt exception in main thread is much much nicer.\''

b'b" Montellese is partly right: Current behaviour:1. Service scripts are polling for abortRequested2. Service scripts get killed with SystemExit exception New behaviour would be1. Service scripts are polling for abortRequested2. Service scripts are getting abortRequested flag set this time3. Service scripts get killed by unhandled KeyboardInterrupt Exception nearly at the same time This is because of current scripts don\'t catch the KeyboardInterrupt Exception. So adding this doesn\'t alter the behaviour for current scripts but it also doesn\'t allow them to shutdown like they ment to. So i agree that the overall behaviour is the same but this PR would also be able to FIX the shutdown of current scripts (be leaving the raise of KeyboardInterrupt out). Not sure what should be achieved in that regard. Is there some API version or so
column11: so that we could introduce this with a API version bump?"'

column10: b'b" They can shut down perfectly fine by catching the exception. Which shouldbe normal python practice.The change in behavior is minimal (the forced system exit is has been therefor a while) and most scripts don\'t need to shut down cleanly. And hanginggui for 5 seconds is ugly."'

b'b" Hm but why is it that before ronie updated  with polling for the abortRequested flag that script used to hang my XBMC for over a minute on shutdown because XBMC was waiting on it to stop? Another addon that regularly manages to  my XBMC installation on shutdown is Trakt Utilities (which is why I disabled it a few days ago). I didn\'t mean to say that KeyboardInterrupt is a bad idea
column11: it is actually a good idea. But I bet that none of the scripts in the official repo which use the polling of abortRequested also catch the KeyboardInterrupt. So adding that isn\'t really a fix it just changes the behaviour to something that does exactly the same and doesn\'t solve the problem for existing scripts (for Eden) as long as they are not updated to catch KeyboardInterrupt."'

column10: b'b" If they don\'t catch it
column11: it should also abort though."'

b"b' refactor dvdplayervideo demux queue to include codec buffering'"

b"b' This extends the dvdplayervideo demux queue to include possible codec buffering. Some hw codecs run external buffers and needs to include these buffers in making decisions during video . Right now we attempt to keep external buffing to a min and pray that we do not cause too much thrashing. This refactor eliminates these games. This is slightly tricky as the demux queue can be used by size or by time and you have to handle both cases as you do not know which is being used. 1) move dvdplayer demux message queue private and add accessors.2) change accessors to better indicate their functions and remove unused functions.3) extend queues to include possible codec buffering.'"

b"b' Initial work on passing flags to IFile objects to allow for special handling of context.'"
b'b" This patch set adds in passing the CFile\'s flags to the IFile. CacheFiles are handled
column11: by altering the flags set to be safe flags. This is required to fix bugs that require the IFile implimentations to know the context they are working in. New flags will be added to  and can then be checked against by IFile implementations. ( ie
column12: not wanting to set CURLOPT_LOW_SPEED_LIMIT on CurlFiles that are media playback
column13: as a pause or skip-backwards may cause the speed limit to triger and playback to be aborted. See url  )"'

column10: b'b" You\'ll want to review the cosmetics here there\'s several lines ending in whitespace
column11: indents are not set at 2 spaces using spaces
column12: and { } should be on separate lines as per the rest of the code. IFile.h is included in File.h
column13: and is almost always going to be included wherever you\'ll be using the flags
column14: so why not have them there instead of introducing the new file? Lastly
column15: SetFlags() only makes sense in the Open() call setting it afterwards is fruitless
column16: right?  So it might be that setting it in Open() might make the most sense. Also
column17: you haven\'t handled the redirection exceptions at all by the looks. @elupus I suspect a word or two from you might be useful before too much effort is put into this."'

column10: b"b' We are fussed about cosmetics.  We do not accept code that has unnecessary cosmetic changes or that does not conform with our coding guidelines.  These are demands we place on ourselves
column11: and we expect contributions to the project to follow these in the same way. As for the exception handling
column12: see CFile::Open.  the IFile::Open() call can throw an exception which causes a new IFile object to be returned
column13: which is then subsequently opened.  You need to set flags on that as well. The current flags are useless past Open
column14: and I presume that other flags will be as well
column15: so having a SetFlags() function that is essentially useless unless called prior to Open() at the very least needs to be documented as such. In the meantime
column16: I suggest waiting on @elupus as he may have suggestions as to how to best remedy the problem you are having.'"

column10: b'b" OK after some investigation  fails because XBMC is unable to delete the temporary file it creates during the test. It is however able to delete the copy of the temporary file. The question is whether being able to delete the temporary file is part of the requirement that the test succeeds or fails. The copy functionality works but the delete doesn\'t but the test is called .  fails in CFile::Rename() and  also fails because it can\'t delete the initial temporary file (it can delete the copy of the temporary file). So there seems to be a problem with the generation and deletion of the temporary file. I\'m not 100% but I think the problem is that the temporary file is created by CTempFile and on creation it\'s opened and not closed again. So any call to delete etc will fail because there\'s still an open handle to that file. The problem is that our file factory does not know about CTempFile from the testing code and therefore doesn\'t forward the calls to Delete() etc to the CTempFile implementation. If I add a call to Close() right after calling OpenForWrite() in CTempFile::Create() these tests pass but a lot of other tests fail because they probably assume that the file is open and can be read from / written to."'
b"b' OK with these additional calls to CTempFile::Close() all the tests in TestFileOperationJob will pass: url '"

b"b' [PVR] Add timeshift support (requires backend support)'"
b"b' This PR extends the PVR API to allow pause
column11: rewind and forward of LiveTV streams if the backend supports it. A PVR addon can tell XBMC for each individual backend channel whether it supports timeshifting for this channel or not.XBMC will enable the corresponding buttons if the selected channel can timeshift. Summary of the changes:Confluence skin extended with extra buttonsPVR API extended with PauseLiveStream() and PauseRecordedStream() functions to tell the PVR addon that XBMC paused playback. This can be used by the pvr addon to pause for example a RTSP stream.PVR channel updated with a CanTimeshift property'"

b"b' [AE] Allow sink to decide how or if it can be suspended'"
b"b' Abstract  to sink to let it pre-process or decline a Suspend state. This replaces previous behaviour of destroying the sink on suspend and allows the sink to shitdown gracefully or decline
column11: as well as force a re-init on Resume if required. Moved  code to inline function to clean up SoftAE::Run() and added better comments Written in light of reported issue with ALSA and Droid sinks on suspend. WASAPI has been implemented here other platform help requested!'"

b'b" If the sink knows that it is (or should be) suspended
column11: it will know much better what to do when idle. I\'d really like to see this logic dropped out of the engine and handled in the sinks instead. It\'s far too complicated trying to keep up with all of the possible states here. Imo it should go like this:Drop the continuous streaming handling in the engine
column12: sink decides. Some platforms can handle this and some can\'t
column13: don\'t try to override them.Always fire data at the sink
column14: even if it\'s silence.Engine has a number of possible states: . Advertise which.Engine fires a public event when going from idle->playing or the reverse.Sink does a engine->() if we\'re suspended. If done that way
column15: there\'s no need for any blind waits
column16: there\'s no  latency
column17: and we\'re sleeping for the _exact_ right time every time. Am I missing an obvious reason for keeping this stuff in the engine?"'

column10: b'b\' @TheUni thx for the review. I agree with where you\\\'re going on the above
column11: especially about it getting complicated in the engine code thus the inlining for that logic. Sleeping for the exact wait time is ideal (as long as Resume is immediate). If I have a concern it would be the narrow window we\\\'re in. Not sure I can get the above done (nor allow time for other platforms to comply)
column12: and I\\\'m doubtful the above would meet the "bug-fix" criteria in feature-freeze. If it would be acceptable post-merge-window we can skip this and I can put something together more in line with the above. If not this would be the stop-gap to correct the issues you\\\'re seeing with ALSA where the engine does not allow the sink to pre-process that state.\''

b'b" Alsa will block in AddPackets. The snd_pcm_wait() blocks (using select() internally) while waiting for free space in the alsa buffer. So it\'s not sucking up too much cpu time. @DDDamian From my experience
column11: Alsa simply isn\'t reliable enough to bring  all the time. I would be thrilled if someone proved me wrong here
column12: but I spent tons of time trying to get it to play nice on my various hardware
column13: with nothing to show for it. Until then
column14: we\'ll need to leave the SoftSuspend disabled there."'

b'b" I understand your portability concerns. The problem is: Gentoo provides libnfs-1.3.0 alright
column11: but they unconditionally configure it with enable-tirpc. The reason for that
column12: according to the Gentoo devs
column13: is that libc will drop rpc support soon
column14: so libtirpc seems the only route. enable-libtirpc
column15: on the other hand
column16: breaks NFS browsing for XBMC
column17: because here
column18: the libc RPC headers are used unconditionally
column19: despite libnfs\'s pkgconfig stating otherwise. We had a long debugging session in the mentioned libnfs issue to find that. Only to find out that the maintainer is about to drop external RPC support completely. Thus
column20: there are 3 (4) options:convince the Gentoo devs to drop enable-tirpc for 1.3.0 -fix XBMC\'s configure to use the correct rpc headers and libs (i.e. libtirpc vs. libc)update libnfs to the next release
column21: which comes without external rpc dependenciesLeave Gentoo users with a broken NFS implementation Now
column22: which option do you want to you choose? ;-)"'

column11: Cory Fields" notifications@ wrote:Sure, So, my change isn\\\'t strictly-speaking necessary, but it reduces a lot ofthe maintainability risk that comes with that section of code. Repeatingchecks like : if (guess->GetName () == implementation || implementation == "auto") isfine for the first time, but then you have to update all of them in caseyou decide to change "auto
column12: or the method name or whatever. Also
column13: having alot of code where you\\\'ve got allocation and frees close to each other isrisky too because its easy to accidentally miss a free or double free whenyou didn\\\'t intend to. (This is also why I have guess->Initialize () in a destructor because ofthe risk of new throwing an exception
column14: having it in a destructor makes itexception safe) As for debuggability I don\\\'t think that\\\'s so much of an issue. Mostdebuggers will show you the template arguments in the function name
column15: andthen also
column16: its the same code for the check-and-verify bits too (becausethey operate through a PV-interface). As for readability I think this change makes it clearer that the sameprocess is applied to each constructed object
column17: rather than the readerchecking carefully to make sure there isn\\\'t a slightly different procedurefor each object. The best way in which readability can be improved is probably just toimprove those function names (I\\\'m sure they\\\'re not 100% right). The reason why I proposed this change generally was because I was lookingat the requirements for wayland and mir
column18: and then I realized that we\\\'d beadding another three copies of this code in the future (X11
column19: wayland
column20: mir)and that maybe it would get a little silly if we had 6 repetitions.\''

column10: b'b\' "(This is also why I have guess->Initialize () in a destructor because of the risk of new throwing an exception
column11: having it in a destructor makes it exception safe)" I would suggest to prevent any exceptions from leaving your destructor as exceptions in destructors may result in undefined behavior and you will not know that guess->Initialize() guarantees to be exception free.\''

column10: b'b\' That\\\'s a very good point I had not considered this before. Perhaps theinitialize-in-a-destructor model is not the best there\\\'s no inconsistentstate to worry about here in the allocation functions (eg if new throws)
column11: so I think I\\\'ll refactor that to be a function that initializes the nativetype and then returns true. That way we can do this: return InitializeEGLNativeType (nativeType);On Mar 19

column12:
Cory Fields" notifications@ wrote:Yeah, I generally try to avoid macros because they\\\'re basicallyundebuggable. Templates are debuggable but template errors suck.That was something I meant to ask about boost and C++11. Some people likethem, others don\\\'t. I don\\\'t know what the view is here. As for the boost I\\\'m using here boost::noncopyable basically declares allcopy constructors and copy assignment operators as private, so that youdon\\\'t weird behaviour from implicit copies of something that you meant tobe an object type. That being said, it won\\\'t be necessary anymore once I make the relevantchange. Putting the call to Initialize () in a destructor was a good ideaat the time, but I don\\\'t want to do that anymore.Thanks. As for your other question the naming. column10: b"b' fixed memory leak on minimized due to missing deletion of unused textures (fixes #14245)'"

b'b" I made this a pr since it looks like m_AppActive is also used for SDL and android. Using multiimage controls lead to heavy memory leaking when being minimized because we don\'t free the unused textures anymore. I just removed the hole block because on windows doing a FreeUnusedTextures() inside that block costs more cpu power than process the whole Render path (7% to 5%).Given that we just want to leave early to save resources this makes no sense at least on win. What I need to know is if this has counter effects on the other platforms using m_AppActive."'
b'b" Pretty sure we can drop the m_AppActive diddling for android
column11: we handle it with a bigger hammer now (m_renderGUI). Looks like each platform has implemented this idea on its own at some point
column12: it\'s probably really in need of some unification. Fine for android."'

column10: b'b" I\'ve added m_AppActive to the lowfps bool which lowers resources needed when running minimized."'

b'b" @wsoltys this indeed fixes the huge mem leak however there\'s still another small leakage present in the orders of 10.Same testcase as in ticket (or perhaps also set The Big pictures screensaver and minimize) Edit:could be unrelated and something else leaking however when minimized it got from 100mb to 175mb."'
b'b" @wsoltys If you\'re going to go to the trouble of trying to minimize usage
column11: I highly recommend taking a look at m_renderGUI (and SetRenderGUI). With this set to false
column12: XBMC is essentially running headless. We use it in Android and on tiny arm cpus
column13: we get down to ~0% cpu usage. It takes care of sleeping. If we could unify this behavior in CApp
column14: then all platforms could just call CApp::SetRenderGUI(false) when they don\'t need to render (minimized
column15: obscured
column16: etc)."'

Not sure but I guess it came back with enabling dirty regions. Before deleting a texture you have to make sure it is not in use anymore. You know this after buffers have been swapped: url '"
b'b" Hmm
column11: I\'m not sure how you can have a texture in the m_unusedTextures list that can still be in use by the GPU if a texture is no longer being used by all controls
column12: then there would be a dirty region set as the last control gives up the texture
column13: so that a flip will occur anyway
column14: and the texture would then be unused at next ProcessSlow() ? (Note that moving the freeing of unused textures to ProcessSlow will inadvertently hide any bug that exists here as it\'s only called every 500ms rather than every app loop)"'

column10: b'b" I am just a bit scared that this could make the problem even harder to track down. Once every 500ms we have the same sequence as before
column11: right? I don\'t see any obvious problems either
column12: just investigating in this area. There may be an issue with dr but I am far away from being sure. A user reports losing vsync on Linux (Nvidia) once every 30 hours. The last tests with dr disabled have shown a negative (no issue). Not confirmed
column13: needs much more testing."'

column10: b'b" For sure it would make it harder to track. :)  It won\'t make you feel any better
column11: but I think there\'d already be a small chance of a hard to track problem anyway :).  The large texture manager is handled the same way
column12: though that has at least a 2 second delay between when the texture is last used by a control and the texture being deleted
column13: which makes it somewhat unlikely that it\'ll still be used by the GPU. Still
column14: if you think there\'s potentially a real issue
column15: then one option is to move it back to Render() and then get rid of the code block that was causing Render() to be skipped when minimised in the Frodo branch.  This would also mean that we don\'t reduce texture removal to only every 500ms.  The master branch doesn\'t need this fix at all

column10: b"b' [FFmpeg] version bump to n1.2 (rev e820e3a)'"
b'b\' FFmpeg version bump to n1.2 (rev e820e3a).  This solves a bunch of more or less serious problems that we currently struggle with in version 0.10.2
column11: for instance preventing users to watch certain content types
column12: hangs or causes stuttering video playback. Also
column13: n1.2 is the last ffmpeg version that supports the old api. Essentially
column14: this upgrade contains the following files and directories:dir: FFmpeg n1.2 fork (rev e820e3a) including all necessary xbmc add on patches.dir: This directory contains all the XBMC add-on patches applied to ffmpeg n1.2.file: -patches  Brief description of the xbmc add on patches.file: -patches  Contains obsolete xbmc custom patches that were NOT applied to n1.2.file: Win32 build script that generates the include file DllPaths_generated_win32_ffmpeg.h and is called from .file: Deals with the decrepated version av_read_frame_flush -file: When ffmpeg is configured for osx then remove duplicate log2_tab.o from libavcodec.a
column15: libavformat.a and libswresample.afile:  & Resolves dllAvFilter dependencies of LibPostProc that previously required LD_LIBRARY_PATHGeneral adjustments to n1.2 (files)  file: file: file: file: file: file: file: file: -preprocessor- Updated version that manages  assembler optimizations. Source: -preprocessor
column16: rev 76a72f00e (Dec 03
column17: 2012).file: Win32 build script adjusted to ffmpeg n1.2file: Win32 build script that generates the include file DllPaths_generated_win32_ffmpeg.h.file: DllPaths_win32.h is now modified to include the auto-genrerated file "DllPaths_generated_win32_ffmpeg.h".\''

column10: b'b\' My findings regarding the  issue:Brief summary:  Currently Mingw-Make does only work when ffmpeg is checked out with =false under win32 (as most already may have guessed!) It\\\'s quite odd that mingw-make can\\\'t cope with crlf endings since I guess this was not an issue with the old 0.10.2 ffmpeg.  Are we missing a "miniwg" settings file or something like that?Background:  The build env that was used is based on a ffmeg repo cloned from the ffmpeg n1.2 fork. Since it was a git repo it was also possible to utilizes local config settings like =false. As soon as the PR made it into the xbmc master repo
column11: ffmpeg just became a regular directory which makes it impossible to use local git config settings.Temporary workaround:  A very temporary solution I\\\'ve tested is to re-checkout ffmpeg with =false but that is obviously a rather ugly solution!Possible solutions?  Does it exist any platform settings (local or global) in the minigw  environment that enables Mingw-Make to accept crlf instead of just lf? Can someone with deeper skills in this area please explain if anything like that is possible?  ## Other ideas? I\\\'ll continue to dig deeper into this issue and see if i may find anything in the old 0.10.2 environment. Any type of feedback or ideas is of course welcome...\''

b"b' [] Support external audio tracks with dvdplayer'"

b'b" This PR adds the possibility to play external audio tracks together with video files.The original PR is here:#1337. Currently there is no support for extraction from the filename. It can easily be added after #1365 got merged
column11: the code for that is in my repo. I implemented it with minimal code  in mind. The idea is to  audio packets from internal tracks if an external track is selected. The read rate is hard-coded at the moment
column12: maybe someone has a solution for that flaw. I\'m not sure if this leads to performance issues on low power devices. There are at least 2 shortcomings at the moment:playback stops if the selected external track reaches its end (before the end of the video stream)seeking may lead to temporary stutter Two other approaches that came to my mind areallow more than one player at a time and mix or prioritize the streams video and audio frames separately
column13: i.e.
column14: extend this idea: #1137  BTW this was my first contact with c++ and xbmc-code
column15: so it\'s certainly far from perfect."'

b'b" Hello! Sorry to drop in like this with a non-technical message
column11: but I just wanted to let you know @ace20022 that I am really excited by the possibilities of your work here
column12: and I really appreciate all the time you\'ve spent on this. Just by jumping around the various forum posts about this project I\'ve gotten a sense of what a long and frustrating journey it has been to get to this point. The support for external audio tracks seems like such an obviously needed feature (I\'m sure that the kind of people who use XBMC are the kind of people who like listening to DVD commentaries) that I\'m surprised you\'ve had to do so much on your own. I wish I could offer some useful help
column13: but my coding skills are nowhere near strong enough. The best I can do is cheer you on from the sidelines and let you know that your work is not in vain. I can hardly wait for the chance to try out what you\'ve been doing... my commentary tracks have been silent for too long! Thank you!"'

b"b' [RFC] Protect Player!'"
b'b" When I was looking at the action handling stuff re. the ACTION_ (other pull request) I came across the very many calls to the player from different places
column11: and thought it wasn\'t very clean. The idea is to remove direct access to CApplication::m_pPlayer
column12: by making it a proxy (CApplicationPlayer) to the real player object. Additional benefits are:remove unnecessary null-checks e.g. when also checking IsPlayingXXX calling CApplication::IsPlaying / IsPaused instead of player\'s equivalentslocking of the player operations (thread safety)move player management logic out of CApplication into CApplicationPlayer"'

column10: b"b' Also needs locking :) url '"
b'b" @davilla wouldn\'t it be better to wrap the locks + player calls in CApp methods
column11: thus avoiding the proliferation of player locks throughout the codebase?"'

column10: b'b" Please don\'t add wrappers in app. It hides the lock. Players should belocked internally
column11: and only called from app thread where the pointer can\'tchange behind our back."'

column10: b'b" I\'m still contemplating locks + player calls
column11: on one hand some sort of wrapper is cleaner but on the other hand
column12: the locks get hidden and people forget about it and do bad things. Not sure how to resolve it. @elupus
column13: his code or mine ? The reason I added locking was it is possible to create a python addon that handles player in one thread and another thread checking IsPlaying (or some other call that access player)
column14: there was a race between them when the player was destroyed and IsPlaying jumped off the edge of the world in a random fashion. Making player a shared-ptr might help and would prevent this type of crash but that means at some time
column15: there could be two players in existence
column16: one
column17: the other  and different parts of XBMC referencing the different players. Is that an issue that would cause hidden and hard to debug problems ?"'

column10: b'b" Biggest problem with two players is that they use global objects(rendermanager and current video settongs). This really should be resolved
column11: but isn\'t yet. That said. I still think adding a GetPlayer() function that return a sharedptr
column12: is the best.The GetPlayer() still need to have an internal lock since copy of a sharedptr is not threadsafe. Then a null check on that copy should be done before use. It should exist so short it aught to work most of the time :)."'

column10: b'b" the only danger i see with hiding the locks is that somebody goes and does stupid things near an inner loop. is that what you fear @elupus? what i had in mind here is some info handler
column11: separate from the player. and have that handler be the only thing that pulls the player. then we can easily control the accesses and we don\'t end up with naughty locks inside the players which is very likely to lead to huge performance regressions (ref pap rewrite...) i haven\'t surveyed the code to see if all direct-to-player calls fall in the info extraction category but there should be very little besides those (obviously player control but this is already centralized i believe). this by itself does not solve the problem
column12: but it makes it much easier to resolve since we now have a very manageable setup."'

column10: b'b" There is also a ton of \'player\' stuff going on inside of CApp
column11: might be time to clean all that up into a CPlayer class to encapsulate m_pPlayer which also provides the controlled access be it locks or otherwise."'

column10: b'b" Well for info extraction
column11: player still need an internal lock since it is running it\'s own thread.  But I absolutely do think we should have a CPlayer class to handle all the stuff connected to playlist\'s and and stacks.. One option could be to move it into the PlayListPlayer()
column12: but i suppose that one is messy as it is. On that note... we should really get rid of the ability to play something without a playlist."'

column10: b"b' How about creating a CPlayer class that would inherit from IPlayer
column11: therefore could be a player singleton for CApplication. This way most logic could remain intact. The CPlayer would wrap the calls with locking  to the actual player or return default values if no current player?'"

column10: b"b' The point of cplayer would to get the code out of application. And not hidethe locks.'"
b'b" closing for now
column11: as this is now too far off from the original intent. I\'m going to think about it and try a couple things before resubmitting. Thanks for the useful feedback and hints."'

column10: b'b\' reopened. I\\\'ve pushed new commit. Basic idea:CApplicationPlayer class acts as an always-available proxy to the actual player. All calls to player go through this proxy.CApplicationPlayer handles the locking of the playerCApplicationPlayer allows some CApplication "player logic" to be moved out (like creation / opening / closing) @garbear \\\'s comments are addressed locally but looking for some more feedback before pushing update.\''

column10: b'b" The base class implementation of the virtual Render() should be called
column11: regardless of whether the control has anything to render or not.  Until very recently
column12: not doing so would mean some control state information would not be correctly updated.  This has since been changed
column13: but I think it is worth keeping as no doubt something will drop into the base class\'s Render() function again in time
column14: and we don\'t want to be caught out with assumptions not being satisfied.  This is the reason we don\'t early return on the main if() block. I don\'t mind making the change when I have time unfortunately I don\'t have a lot of it at the moment
column15: so it could take some time."'

b"b' Built in function PlayMedia does not play music folders'"
b'b" Following specification
column11: PlayMedia should be able of playing content offolders
column12: either with content of video or music. An issue has been found by which passing a music folder to thisfunction won\'t play its content. However
column13: if the folder contains videofiles it works. This function internally enumerates files by extension
column14: and when afolder is received
column15: only video extensions are searched. This commit addmusic extensions too to the search
column16: solving the issue."'

column10: b'b" A problem with this might be that it could result in a mixed playlist of videos and songs if the passed in folder contains both videos and songs. XBMC can\'t handle mixed playlists."'
b'b" Hi
column11: I don\'t think is a problem
column12: because in this case it would play videos. Look at the fragment of source code: So with mixed content
column13: the resulting playlist would be interpreted as PLAYLIST_VIDEO and music files would be skipped. Resulting patch will play folders of music
column14: video
column15: and video when there is music and video in the same folder. Without the patch
column16: music folders are not played at all. Best regards."'

column10: b'b" But the resulting playlist would still contain music items. Maybe it would be worth adding some additional logic to the loop to figure out if there are music items AND video items in the list and if so
column11: run another loop to remove all the music items before passing the list on to the playlist. That way we\'d end up with either a clean music playlist (no removing necessary) or a clean video playlist (maybe removing necessary)."'

column10: b'b" Hi
column11: I\'ve just incorporated your suggestion
column12: please look at the last commit. Now when the folder has mixed content
column13: the resulting behaviour is to build the resulting playlist with only video files. So:Play folder with only music -Play folder with only video -Play folder which has music and video -Best regards."'

b'b\' To fix your branch
column11: do the following: you\\\'ll get an editor with 5 lines
column12: one line for every commit. Every line starts with "pick" and then the commit hash and the commit message. Remove the third and fourth lines (the merge commit and the revert of the merge commit). Change the "pick" to a "fix" for the last two lines to combine all three commits into a single one. Then save the file and close the editor. That will remove those two commits completely. You don\\\'t need to be on latest  for the PR to be mergeable.If after that you still want to get the latest commits from
column13: you can use And as @MartijnKaijser mentioned
column14: never work in your master branch. Always create a new branch based on your master branch using \''

column15: libwayland-
column16: libwaylandand  are now loaded as dynamic libraries so that there is no runtime dependency if we want to build in wayland support. Unfortunately
column17: that comes at a cost we are no longer able to use a lot of the autogenerated protocol boilerplate and must instead use the protocol directly. As such
column18: any changes to this branch which are strictly protocol related should really be encapsulated in the objects found in the xbmc::wayland namespace. Due to differences in the way the protocol operates between wayland 1.1 and 1.2+
column19: there is no guaruntee that anything in the xbmc::wayland namespace is going to be running in the same thread. Usually this is not a problem
column20: as the wayland objects are just there to manage the connection with a compositor in the background and don\'t interact with the rest of xbmc. The only shared state is the available output modes and xbmc does not make any assumptions about deterministic access to these anyways. There is unit
column21: integration and acceptance test coverage for this branch. Acceptance tests require the weston SDK in order to be built. They also require a weston binary to be available on the system. They shouldn\'t require any special graphics hardware the tests use the no-op renderer so there\'s no checking for things with EGL_bind_wayland_display or the like. I\'ll need some testing to verify this though. Screenshot:![wayland-on-weston-on-x]url  Note if you\'re testing on wayland-drm: Video playback will skip and stutter. The reason for this is probably because xbmc doesn\'t have access to your audio hardware from the console session
column22: so SoftAE will keep resetting itself as its unable to push any data to PA. 12:55  smspillaz: and as for weston-launch

column10: b'b\' The revised patchset contains:1. More comments (approximately 1000 lines more)
column11: especially in funky areas and along class boundaries to show where the main integration points are2. enable-wayland now implies enable-gles3. Some small build fixes (missing #include
column12: not sure how I missed that one). I haven\\\'t done any squashing yet. There seems to be a mixed verdict on squashing and its one of those things that\\\'s more difficult to reverse once its done (reverting to a previous HEAD with reflogs doesn\\\'t count because there may have been subsequent changes). As such
column13: I\\\'ve left the history as-is. I think that more squashing could potentially be a good thing
column14: however I\\\'m mindful of the fact that squashing some parts together could be a week-long job handling conflict fallout
column15: especially where files were split up. We\\\'ve got automated test coverage on most of this code so there\\\'s not a huge amount of risk involved
column16: but its effectively letting the perfect be the enemy of the good. If the verdict is that squashing is desired before merge
column17: then I\\\'ll go ahead and squash based on the plan I outlined earlier. Otherwise it might be better to just leave it be. Hopefully the revised documentation should help people a little bit in navigating their way around the codebase. I apologize that it has grown to a substantial size
column18: although I\\\'d advise looking past the number of lines changed and more to the structure. I\\\'ve tried as much as possible to ensure that the codebase forms a directed acyclic graph of nodes
column19: with the following lifecycle: WinSystemEGL creates EGLNativeTypeWayland which creates: -XBMCConnection creates a new xbmc::wayland::Registry object which listens on the main connection for any new global interfaces. Once a global interface becomes available (usually immediately) it creates a wrapper object for it (eg
column20: Compositor
column21: Shell
column22: Seat
column23: Output). The Seat global interface is injected into CWinEventsWayland which manages its internal state through xbmc::wayland::InputFactory xbmc::wayland::InputFactory contains a PointerProcessor
column24: KeyboardProcessor and EventLoop. EventLoop is the implementation detail for CWinEventsWayland and represents the wayland message pipe. Calling CWinEvents::MessagePump will dispatch either wayland or partially processed wayland events for further processing. Both are of the former "processor" classes are registered with the xbmc::wayland::Pointer and xbmc::wayland::Keyboard once they come online. When a new pointer or keyboard event occurs
column25: they are forwarded on to the former two classes for "processing" where they are turned into XBMC_Event structures and forwarded on to CApplication. Since the entire state of the backend is encapsulated in these objects
column26: that part of the backend is effectively torn down as soon as they are destructed. Once EGLNativeTypeWayland is gone
column27: there should be no more owning references to any other objects in the system related to this backend. Please feel free to ask me questions before merging. I\\\'d hope that there is some general understanding of how things work as opposed to "its a monster but we want it". I\\\'ve tried to make the design as straightforward as possible
column28: but some abstractions are a little contrived because dependencies needed to be separated for testing purposes. Also consider reading the test code it should provide some insight into how things are supposed to work.\''

column10: b"b' [droid] Store the log file in a user-accessible location'"
b'b" The log file () on Android is stored in // which can only be accessed with root permissions.With the huge work on Android by XBMC team; and the fragmentation of the Android platform
column11: logs are very crucial but a lot of Android users including myself don\'t have easy access to the log file due to the need of root permissions to  it. This PR fixes this issue. This patch changes the log path to:// which is accessible by all file managers and ftp servers with no root privileges needed. Note: the Wiki\\\\* states that the current log is stored on the sdcard. On my three phones and the tablet it is stored inside of /data/ which is only root-accessed. This patch changes the path to a more consistent path which is the one stated above (the same folder as ).  url "'

b"b' X11 improvements
column11: fixes
column12: drop SDL'"

column10: b"b' This is maintained drop SDL branch + lots of other improvements and fixes.I have not submitted this earlier because the code needs some cleanup and I was busy with audio. In order to avoid further confusion I would like to communicate that there was ongoing work on X11 behind the scenes. Thinking of it I have to say that it would be kind of silly not considering this work for Gotham. It is much better than what we have in current master.supports multiple monitors on a single X screensupports monitors on multiple X screensxrandr screen rotations (initial trigger for this endeavor)fallback to other monitor if e.g. projector or AVR disconnectsauto switch to desired monitor when AVR get connectedfix VideoReferenceClock for multiple monitorsfix VideoReferenceClock for systems having no nvidia-settings (OpenElec)add some missing keys like XF86XK_Sleep Note that this code has been used by OpenElec for more than a year. Also most AMD users on Linux have tested this over months. @smspillaz would be great if you could comment this version.'"
b"b' Remember
column11: dropping SDL is on the white list for gotham. So you have anothermonth to work on getting things in order. Any of the other bits are just a matter of carefully crafted commitmessages. :)'"

column10: b'b" I\'ll do a quick code review now
column11: although one thing I will mention more broadly:Is that really something we want? Multi-screen (as opposed to multi-monitor) is an X usecase that has largely fallen by the wayside. The only reason why you\'d want to use it is for multi-head with SLI on NVIDIA hardware
column12: but even that is probably going to go away soon with RandR provider objects. Most window managers have either stopped explicitly supporting it or stopped maintaining their codepaths for it years ago (and many of them are broken as a result) and I suspect it is going to be one of those things that will be deprecated-by-lack-of-maintenance in \'s XServer implementation soon. Supporting it introduces a substantial amount of complexity that might not be worth the tradeoff to be honest."'

column10: b"b' Well
column11: it does already work. The point is that on NVidia systems you get tearing when setting up multiple monitors on a single screen. Having multiple screens works fine. With regard to video playback NVidia proprietary driver is still best solution for Linux. As long as this fact does not change I think we should consider this use case.'"

column10: b"b' I can confirm @FernetMenta latest patch fixes the mp4 file.One minor issue you get to see the visualisation start up (just for a second) when playing a file with audio and video presumably because the audio stream is detected first.'"

b'b" I sent some refactoring to @margro url  I summarize:avformat_find_stream_info is slowfor mpeg-ts we detect program changes. after such a change we need a method to get stream information anywayavformat_find_stream_info rewinds to pos 0 after analysis which IMO is a bad idea for live streamsmaybe add an advanced setting for skipping streaminfo in general? @elupus what\'s your opinion on this?"'

b"b' For the file playback case:Is assume avformat_find_stream_info is only slow for non-indexed formats (mpegps).I assume it is fast for indexed formats (). I believe it avformat_find_stream_info is not just slow for non-indexed files
column11: it is inaccurate (an arbitrary amount of time is parsed
column12: and is a stream is not present during that time it is missed). Would skipping avformat_find_stream_info for non-indexed formats
column13: but using it for index formats be reasonable?'"

column10: b"b' Or maybe we should limit the time for analysis in general. '"

b'b" @FernetMenta: Added and tested your changes. Will squash them later.Limiting the analysis time (e.g. only for Live-TV) will work also. That was what I\'ve used before.The problem is only that late appearing streams are missing."'

b'b" see url there\'s another commit there related to this.also line 802 -setting AVDISCARD_ALL might also only be valid for mpeg2/h264. It really depends on what the FFMpeg codec does when discarding. Generally you want to skip the actual decode but allow the codec to parse the stream info."'
b"b' I would not eat packets for a single stream. In case we know there is video and we are waiting for an IDR frame
column11: we should eat all packets (audio as well). This is how I do it in vnsi.'"

column10: b"b' yep'"
b"b' I really dislike this. Please fix ffmpeg :(. '"
b'b" Fixing ffmpeg would require major work I think
column11: It\'s designed a very static situation and to try very hard to obtain correct info no matter the cost in start up time. Even decoding several frames which is a real hurt under ARM with HD content. I\'ve looked at what it does and I don\'t see a  way to make a stream with known characteristics
column12: startup faster. In general
column13: we take 5 to 10 seconds (on ARM) after selection before there is any hint of a switch.  Maybe FFMpeg debs would have a clue on how to handle this."'

column10: b"b' The problem with ffmpeg is that the parser has no access to the decode extradata functions. fixing this and add a flag to ffmpeg to force continuous parsing of SPS would eliminate the need of instantiating a decoder here and also calling find_stream_info.Not sure how difficult this would be.'"
b"b' You would still have to resolve FFMpeg doing full frame decodes when probing. This really hurts to do N-frames of 1080p on ARM. Each frame can take several hundred milliseconds to decode.'"
b'b" Does anyone know why FFMpeg even needs to decode instead of parse?Another fact I can\'t explain is why FFMpeg uses much time looking into streams other than ."'
b"b' I did some more investigation. When reading packets through the format context
column11: ffmpeg actually parses the packets. The problem is that it does not expose the desired info. The codec context is only updated when a frame is decoded.'"

Combining #3837 with this PR did not reduce the RTSP switching time
column11: but MPEGTS switching time is further reduced from 4s to 2s."'

column10: b'b" Good to hear. I\'ve also sent #3837 upstream to ffmpeg. Not guaranteed to get in in it\'s current form since they might want to make it optional
column11: since you can\'t force probing of whole files for further headers. But I think it has a very good chance. The next thing we likely should add to our ffmpeg is atleast to turn on discard for the decoding. We don\'t have that on in our code I think. But that only reduces cpu usage somewhat. 4s still seem long. have you tested ffprobe on that file? You can apply: url  to a stock ffmpeg and do: time ffprobe -v debug [rtspurl]. Would be intersting to see the output of that when tuning. "'

column10: b'b" I\'ve dropped the change to set AVDISCARD_ALL on startup upstream as an RFC (it breaks many many ffmpeg regression tests
column11: so it\'s not a good change for us either). Rewind is normal. We should just make sure we can rewind the full probesize in our input stream. what do you mean delivers crap to decoder?"'

column10: b'b" mpegts is no container and the frames prior to first IDR may not be decoded correctly. It makes no sense delivering those packets to decoders. Other players like WMC don\'t either."'
b"b' that sounds more like a bug in the h264 codec. it should not send data to hw decoder that is invalid.'"
b'b" ffmpeg ASSums that it\'s  decoder will handle it sync to IDR. But unless you are going through an ffmpeg decoder
column11: that does not happen. For example
column12: rPI and AML use ffmpeg for demux only and the actual hw decode is handles elsewhere."'

column10: b"b' as for dropping AVDISCARD_ALL
column11: some formats must decode the frame
column12: all of it. Some like h264/mpeg2 can handle AVDISCARD_ALL'"
