column10: b"b' Forced subtitles not working when audio and subtitle language is different'"

b'b\'   ## Bug report ### Describe the bug Here is a clear and concise description of what the problem is:  When playing a video with forced subtitles it doesn\\\'t automatically turn on if the subtitle language is different from the audio language.  For example I have an anime episode with JPN video
column11: JPN audio and ENG forced subtitles
column12: this doesn\\\'t work as subtitles are not enabled by default even with "Forced only" enabled in settings.  If I take the same file and change it in MKVToolNix to ENG video
column13: ENG audio and ENG forced sub without actually changing the files it works and forced subtitles are enabled by default like they should. ## Expected Behavior Here is a clear and concise description of what was expected to happen: Matching language for audio and subtitles should be irrelevant as forced should mean forced no matter what language is set on the file as long as the subtitle is flagged as forced. ## Actual Behavior Only enables forced subtitles by default if audio and subtitle language matches. ## Possible Fix   ### To Reproduce Steps to reproduce the behavior:  1. Take a file and change audio and subtitles language to different languages in MKVToolNix as well as flagging it as forced. 2. Take the same file but this time make another one with audio and subtitle language set to the same language. 3. Play both files in Kodi and the first file will have subtitles disabled even with "Forced only" enabled while the 2nd file will play just fine. ### Debuglog The debuglog can be found here:  []url  ### Screenshots  Here are some links or screenshots to help explain the problem:   ## Additional context or screenshots (if appropriate) Here is some additional context or explanation that might help:  ### Your Environment Used Operating system:  [x] Android  [ ] iOS  [ ] Linux  [ ] OSX  [ ] Raspberry-Pi  [ ] Windows  [ ] Windows UWP Operating system : Android TV 8.0.0  Kodi version: Kodi 18.1 20190228   *note: Once the issue is made we require you to update it with new information or Kodi versions should that be required. Team Kodi will consider your problem report however

column10: b'b\' Well if you\\\'ve used  139460608 then that\\\'s about right. For  it always uses double buffering
column11: furthermore there\\\'s some "backward" cache so the actual forward cache is ~50MB. The fact that it initially *may* increase above this value is because at start we have no backward cache yet
column12: so while filling everything is considered "forward" cache. Depending on how fast it fills and how fast your video progresses forward
column13: forward cache size will decrease and is added to the backward cache. If you double this value (278921216) it gives me about 100MB of forward cache and I think the same thing should happen for you too. Again: I can\\\'t find anything wrong with it.\''

column10: b'b\' Ok. Two things about this. First of all: my bad. I didn\\\'t realize that the number I ended up using was an order of magnitude smaller than the one I was using before.  Second thing is: ok
column11: now I have set up a bigger number and SHIFT+CTRL O reports "forward" in the 700-900 MB range. But RAM usage keeps hovering around 350MB in Windows Task Manager. So I\\\'m not sure where the 768MB of cache I\\\'m seeing now reported are coming from. Are they real?  Also
column12: is there anything that could be done to allow for higher values of cache? 8/16GB machines are not so rare now (at least in Windows x64 environment).  Thanks for the help and sorry for the mishap. I was misled by the "hyper" readfactor value in the wiki and then I misread the new value I input for memsize (always change ONE thing at a time
column13: I know...).  But RAM usage still tells a different story from the one Kodi is internally telling.  ![image]url  Edit: if I go to the Performance tab of Task Manager
column14: under RAM
column15: I see that RAM usage indeed raises by 1GB when playback starts
column16: according to the "forward" value rasing till it hits the 1GB limit.  Sooo... well
column17: probably it\\\'s just due to the way this "cache" is handled internally
column18: that doesn\\\'t register as "Kodi" RAM usage
column19: for some reason. Still it would be nice to be able to exceed 1GB effective cache
column20: if one has the machine to do it. But it\\\'s more of a feature request
column21: probably
column22: to go along with the fact that Windows now has an x64 build. At least it led to the Wiki being corrected
column23: so others won\\\'t be misled as how I was by that example. Maybe it would be good to clearly list the limits for the different values.\''

column10: b'b\' I don\\\'t know anything about Windows\\\'s memory management but the "forward" value I mentioned is the actual memory value used by our file cache
column11: so that\\\'s the one to look at. Furthermore I really don\\\'t see the point of having huge caches: you\\\'re either streaming from the internet with a little help from the cache to buffer glitches or you\\\'re playing something locally. Being able to cache huge files as soon as possible simply isn\\\'t something that improves user experience that much
column12: so I don\\\'t see this happen in the (near) future.\''

b"b'   ## Bug report ### Describe the bug Here is a clear and concise description of what the problem is:  After upgrading my LibreELEC system from Raspberry Pi 3 to Intel J4105 board with 2Gb of RAM I encountered an unexpected issue. It is impossible to use Kodi for a prolonged period of time without encountering an out-of-memory condition which results in OOM killer restarting Kodi. The only addons I ever install and use are vdr-addon
column11: and oscam. This is not an addon issue. The easiest way for me to reproduce the issue is to tune to a high bitrate 4K TV channel and leave it playing for a few hours. During that time the memory usage of  process will progressively grow. Stopping the playback does not make it release the used RAM.  I tried to work around the issue by decreasing the MALLOC_MMAP_THRESHOLD value. I started with 131072 and went as low as 8192. It does not seem to make a huge difference  still grows and is eventually killed by OOM. ## Expected Behavior Here is a clear and concise description of what was expected to happen: I expect  RAM usage not to grow infinitely.  ### Debuglog The debuglog can be found here: url  ### Your Environment Used Operating system:  [ ] Android  [ ] iOS  [x] Linux  [ ] OSX  [ ] Raspberry-Pi  [ ] Windows  [ ] Windows UWP Operating system : LibreELEC  Kodi version: 18.2-rc1 current master  '"

b"b' Fix Sources Path Substitution'"

b'b\' ## Description This fixes the broken media sources path substitution.  The CMediaSourceSettings module loads the media sources before the CAdvancedSettings module loads the path substitutions therefore path substitution fails with CMediaSourceSettings attempting to read the  file from the local rather than the substituted remote path.  This fix ensures that media sources settings are loaded after advanced settings
column11: This also fixes a kodi crash when parsing an  file which has an empty path substitution \\\'from\\\' or \\\'to\\\' node. ## Motivation and Context Discussion at the forums: url The WiKi states that "Path substition for "sources" is broken
column12: and will not be fixed" but it doesn\\\'t seem logical not to fix something for which the majority of code still exists: WiKi Page: url  ## How Has This Been Tested?   Tested with this  file on Windows with remote Windows server:   ## Screenshots (if appropriate):  ## Types of change  [X] **Bug fix** (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) [ ] **Clean up** (non-breaking change which removes non-working

column10: b'b\' That\\\'s fine and you should leave "async epg transfer" activated. With this
column11: will send epg updates immediately to Kodi when tvh has epg updates. Otherwise
column12: Kodi polls for updates with a fixed (user configurable) interval which can lead to out-of-date epg data.  Unfortunately
column13: async epg in combination with local epg cache seems to have a (hard to catch) bug. OTOH
column14: as epg cache gives no real additional value
column15: just turn it off and you will be fine.  I have the feeling that I cannot motivate myself to hunt and fix that bug
column16: to be honest
column17: as I do not use that damn epg cache. ;-)  However
column18: let\\\'s keep this issue open as it is definitely a bug. Maybe somebody else picks up the ball. I think I wont.\''

column12: except your tvh server is located at "the other end of the world with a very slow internet connection".\''

b'b" name: automatic rewind when streaming online content about: when streaminig online content with the .m3u8 file extension
column11: Kodi keeps rewinding  ## Bug report ### Describe the bug Here is a clear and concise description of what the problem is:  Streaming online content for .m3u8 file extensions (with the Retrospect add-on) is creating a rewind while streaming.  ## Expected Behavior Here is a clear and concise description of what was expected to happen: When streamining content
column12: the video should play normal until the end.  ## Actual Behavior For all the streams from the belgium TV channels \'\' and \'\'
column13: which can be streamed with the Retrospect add-on for Kodi
column14: After a while
column15: the stream gets into a loop on which it will rewind X minutes back in time and starts playing from that point again. When it then reached the original loop point
column16: it rewinds again. This keeps happening over and over again until I manually forward past the loop point.  This happens for almost all streams on those 2 TV channels
column17: which releases new content every day.  ## Possible Fix The stream should just play normal. When I download the .m3u8 file with a program like: url  Then the downloaded video plays fine in mp4 format with Kodi.  ### To Reproduce Steps to reproduce the behavior:  1. Open Kodi 2. Install the retrospect add-on from: url  3. Create an account at  4. Add your account to the  channel in the retrospect settings in Kodi. 5. Play a stream from  in Kodi.  A shorter way how the same issue is occuring is with playing the stream directly from Kodi. To do this: 1. Create a file with the extension .strm 2. Add the following URL to the file: url  3. Play the created .strm file with Kodi Please note that these videos are only available for +/7 days and might be geo-locked to Belgium. ### Debuglog The debuglog can be found here: url The log file  is about the stream started with the Retrospect plugin. The log file kodi-log2.log is about the stream started from a .strm file with .m3u8 URL inside. ### Screenshots  Here are some links or screenshots to help explain the problem:  As it is a video

column10: b'b\' That\\\'s most likely the problem
column11: that your share might be a SMB2 share and browsing for SMB shares was a SMB1 feature which is generally disabled on Windows 10 machines. Most likely your NAS is also set to SMB2 now and you should probably use the "Add network location" option for adding sources instead of the "Windows (SMB)" option. After the "Add Network Location" option you get another window where you are able to specify the protocol you want to use (SMB in that case) enter the IP
column12: Username
column13: Password
column14: path to the share etc..... Could you please confirm that this option works for you?  Even if you NAS is set to SMB1 and your Android device is set to SMB2 (not too sure about that)
column15: your Android device won\\\'t see the NAS. That means
column16: that you have enabled SMB1 on your Windows machine and your NAS is also set up to use SMB1
column17: that you are for sure able to see the share on the Windows side. Generally we do not recommend to enable SMB1 as that is known vulnerable. \''

column10: b'b\' Sorry but my NAS\\\'s Samba version is not changed and my QNAP NAS is serving SMBv2:   With older Kodi 18 nightly version I was able to browse. I can confirm that also with "Add network location" and then "Browser" the list is blank.  \''
b"b' And my Nvidia Shield (Android 8) is able to mount (directly without using Kodi) the shares on my NAS.'"
b'b\' I have also tried to enable SMB 3 on my NAS:  But still not able to to  new SMB (Samba) shares from Kodi. But Kodi is still able to access on my movies thanks to ""
column11: Nvidia Shield is still able to access directly to my NAS.  \''

column10: b'b"  As expected. As said
column11: browsing for shares is a SMB1 feature and doesn\'t work for SMB2. If it works on the Windows side then this means your Windows is using SMB1 which is not recommended at all anymore. I would suggest you seek assistance on the forums. As I highly guess we are not talking about a Kodi bug. Currently we are talking about support and support is given at the forums.  If you already have opened a forum thread for this
column12: then please link me to."'

column10: b'b" So
column11: since my Windows PC serve SMBv2 (I configured it in the past) and my NAS is serving SMBv2 and SMBv3 you are saying that it\'s normal that Kodi cannot  for SMBv2/v3?  "'

column10: b'b" >As I highly guess we are not talking about a Kodi bug. Currently we are talking about support and support is given at the forums.  In my opinion it\'s a bug because with Kodi 18.1 I was able to browse....  "'

b'b" Kodi needs to add support for the newer and completely different Windows  discovery process. Until then the legacy discovery process continues to work correctly (as coded) but your network no longer matches the requirements (shares must be downgraded to SMB1 which is a bad idea). This is a bug tracker not a feature-request list and there is no bug so i\'m closing the ticket. Please take further discussion and opinion to the forum. Thanks."'
b"b' @chewitt thank you! I hope Kodi will be upgraded to support  discovery for SMBv2 and SMBv3 soon! Thanks!!'"
